prior_knowledge_digest: Students should have a basic understanding of language structure in their native language, such as nouns, verbs, and simple sentence construction. Familiarity with the concept of a language family and the historical context of ancient Rome will be beneficial. No prior knowledge of Latin is required as this is the introductory lesson.
yesterday_recap: N/A - This is the first day of the course.
misconception_watchlist: Latin is a 'dead' language and not useful
Latin pronunciation is the same as English

primary: Introduce the Latin alphabet and pronunciation
Familiarize students with basic Latin greetings
Understand the historical significance of Latin

lesson_flow.description: Welcome students and introduce the course.
lesson_flow.student_action: Listen and respond to the teacher's greeting.
lesson_flow.teacher_notes: Set a positive tone for the course.

lesson_flow.description: Introduce the Latin alphabet and its pronunciation.
lesson_flow.student_action: Repeat after the teacher and practice pronunciation.
lesson_flow.teacher_notes: Use audio clips to demonstrate correct pronunciation.

lesson_flow.description: Practice basic Latin greetings with the class.
lesson_flow.student_action: Engage in pair activities to practice greetings.
lesson_flow.teacher_notes: Encourage students to use correct pronunciation.

lesson_flow.description: Discuss the historical significance of Latin.
lesson_flow.student_action: Listen and take notes on the importance of Latin.
lesson_flow.teacher_notes: Highlight Latin's influence on modern languages.

lesson_flow.description: Review key points and answer any questions.
lesson_flow.student_action: Ask questions and reflect on what was learned.
lesson_flow.teacher_notes: Ensure students feel comfortable with the material.

lesson_flow.description: Reflect on the faith phrase 'In principio erat Verbum'.
lesson_flow.student_action: Discuss the meaning and significance of the phrase.
lesson_flow.teacher_notes: Connect the phrase to the lesson's themes.
